data.title: Twitch buys UK-founded Bebo for $25M; Infineon gets €1.55B for Cypress deal
data.meta_description: Twitch acquired UK-founded Bebo, while Infineon raised about €1.55 billion to partially fund the Cypress Semiconductor acquisition.
data.text:
TOP NEWS

* Amazon.com Inc.'s Twitch Interactive Inc. acquired U.K.-founded social media platform Bebo Inc., London's The Daily Telegraph reports. Twitch is said to have paid up to $25 million for Bebo, according to TechCrunch.

* Infineon Technologies AG raised about €1.55 billion in capital through a private placement offering, in a bid to partially finance its acquisition of Cypress Semiconductor Corp. The new shares were offered for purchase exclusively to institutional investors through an accelerated bookbuilding process, representing an increase of 10% in the share capital.

PAN-EUROPEAN

* Facebook Inc., Alphabet Inc.'s Google LLC and Twitter Inc. have teamed up with global advertising agencies and brands on an industrywide initiative to "improve digital safety," London's Financial Times reports. European ad agencies, including WPP PLC and Publicis Groupe SA, will be part of the group, which will work to "address harmful and misleading content" and develop a "concrete set" of procedures to protect people and brands online.

U.K. AND IRELAND

* London-based game developer Sensible Object Ltd. said it has been acquired by "Pokémon Go" creator Niantic Inc. for an undisclosed sum and will be renamed Niantic London.

* Digital Colony Management LLC paid an undisclosed sum to purchase U.K. wireless infrastructure company Spyder Facilities Ltd. The acquisition of Spyder expands the private equity firm's U.K. digital infrastructure platform with the addition of more than 5,000 wireless transmission sites, according to a release.

* Vodafone Group PLC priced its cash tender offers to purchase up to $3.1 billion of any and all of certain outstanding debt securities, according to a filing. The principal amount outstanding consists of $500 million for the 4.375% notes due 2021, $1.0 billion for the 2.50% notes due 2022 and $1.6 billion for the 2.950% notes due 2023.

* ITV PLC Head of comedy Saskia Schuster will act on the feedback from an audit, which stated that her shows lack women in scripted commissions, London's The Guardian reports. Schuster will no longer accept shows written by an all-male team.

GERMANY, SWITZERLAND AND AUSTRIA

* German commercial broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media SE announced the official launch of streaming TV app Joyn on Tuesday. The app allows users to livestream 55 channels including those of ProSiebenSat.1, Discovery Inc., Viacom Inc., WELT, Sport1 and public broadcasters ARD and ZDF (DE).

* The Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority contacted the creators of Facebook's cryptocurrency Libra, reports Reuters. However, it is unclear whether the social media company is attempting to acquire regulatory permissions from FINMA.

* German chip supplier Siltronic AG said it has adjusted its outlook for 2019 as it expects higher than expected declines of sales. Due to U.S. and China trade relations, the company expects turnover to decrease up to 15%. It had earlier forecast a decline of between 5% to 10%.

* German publisher Bastei Lübbe AG has sold its puzzle and sudoku magazine business to Amsterdam-based Keesing Media Group BV for an undisclosed sum.

* German publisher Spiegel GmbH plans to join its editorial office of Spiegel Online and the news magazine Der Spiegel under one roof as of autumn 2019. The management teams of the respective companies have agreed on the main points of the merger, reports Handelsblatt.

* Pan-European private equity firm IK Investment Partners, through its IK VIII fund, agreed to buy LAP GmbH Laser Applikationen from capiton. LAP provides laser positioning systems as well as quality assurance software and hardware used during radiotherapy.

FRANCE

* Vivendi SA announced the creation of Vivendi Brand Marketing, which will bring its expertise and original entertainment content to brands globally. Maria Garrido will lead the unit in addition to her role as chief insights officer of Havas SA.

* Orange SA will offer fiber service on Covage's public initiative fiber-to-the-home networks. The territories concerned to date are the departments of Calvados, Essonne, Haute-Savoie, Hérault, Seine-et-Marne and Somme, and the urban areas of Lille and Dunkirk.

* A strike called by public radio unions, with a 41.6% rate of participation, affected Radio France Internationale SA, Le Monde reports. The labor action was staged in protest against CEO Sibyle Veil's cost-cutting plan.

NETHERLANDS, BELGIUM AND LUXEMBOURG

* Altice Europe initiated the sale process for advertising marketplace Teads which it acquired in 2017, Les Échos reports. The sale has attracted interest from more than 10 investment funds, according to sources.

* Belgian company ACTITO Europe (HQ) acquired cloud-based marketing platform smartFOCUS Group PLC, for an undisclosed amount.

* Belgian cloud communications solutions provider Destiny announced it has acquired Netherlands-based OZMO cloud communications, for an undisclosed amount. Destiny currently employs more than 220 employees and is now aiming for an adjusted turnover of €65 million in 2019.

* French company Vivendi could be excluded from voting at shareholder meetings of Mediaset SpA's new Netherlands-based company, reports Reuters, referring to a bylaw of the new holding. Mediaset earlier this month unveiled a corporate overhaul that includes putting the group and its separately listed Spanish unit under a new Dutch holding company as part of a pan-European growth strategy.

* Amsterdam-headquartered VEON has announced the appointment of Muhterem Kaan Terzioğlu as a member of the company's board, as well as 11 previously serving directors.

* Freek Staps has been appointed as the new editor-in-chief of ANP, the Netherlands' national news agency, effective Sept. 1. Staps will succeed Marcel van Lingen, who is now the director of journalism at Talpa Network.

NORDICS

* Norwegian software company Vewd Software AS said that South Korean smart device company Innopia Technologies Inc. will launch an HDMI streaming media player using the Vewd OS. The device will be made available in the second half of 2019.

* Nordic Entertainment Group AB has extended its media rights to Danish soccer in the Nordic region to 2024. Customers can watch the matches on Viaplay AB's streaming service or on TV3 (DK) channels.

* GCI Liberty Inc. has chosen Ericsson to build Alaska's northernmost 5G network, according to a news release. GCI will deploy Ericsson's 3GPP standards-based 5G New Radio hardware and software to 82 macro cell sites across the municipality of Anchorage, Alaska.

* SK Telecom Co. Ltd. signed agreements with Sweden's Ericsson, Finland's Nokia Corp. and Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. for joint research on advanced 5G and 6G mobile network techniques, RCRWireless News reports. The companies will promote development and commercialization of advanced 5G technologies, such as ultra-reliable and low-latency communications, enhanced MIMO, differentiated 28 GHz technology and stand-alone 5G networks.

SOUTHERN EUROPE

* Comcast Corp. unit Sky PLC plans to double its workforce in Portugal to 400 by 2021, up from the current 200 employees, Telecompaper reports, citing Dinheiro Vivo. The Portugal site is reportedly involved in the development of a streaming platform owned by Comcast unit NBCUniversal Media LLC, wants to launch in Portugal in 2020.

* Spanish operator Eurona Wireless Telecom SA is teaming up with MásMóvil Ibercom SA to provide fiber-optic services to a target market comprising more than 7 million homes and businesses.

* The Confederation of African Football has tapped Spanish broadcaster Mediapro to provide a video assistant referee service for the organization's 2019 African Cup of Nations, which will be held June 21 to July 21 in Egypt.

* Telefónica SA's pay TV platform Movistar and Mediapro have jointly rolled out esports channel Movistar Esports Ubeat in Latin America, Advanced Television reports. The channel will be accessible on over-the-top platform Movistar Play.

* Spi International Inc./FilmBox has struck a deal to offer gaming and esports channel Gametoon HD to subscribers of Altice Portugal SA's pay TV operator unit MEO, according to a statement.

EASTERN EUROPE

* Romania Cable Systems & Romania Data Systems will work with Swedish tech giant Ericsson for a live 5G trial in Bucharest's Old Central, which is set for June 27, Telecompaper reports, citing Hotnews.ro.

* The Hungarian government expects to play a key role in the building of 5G networks in the country through a tie-up with the country's telecom operators, Reuters reports, quoting Innovation and Technology Minister László Palkovics.

* Croatian TV towers operator OiV submitted the only bid for the license covering three digital terrestrial TV multiplexes in Croatia, which will run on the DVB-T2 standard, Telecompaper reports. The Croatian Regulatory Authority for Network Industries is expected to decide on the license by July 12.

FEATURED NEWS

Conference Chatter: ConnecTechAsia 2019: Collabs, government support make 5G investments worthwhile: Local governments and public-sector partnerships will play a big role in helping operators recovering from 4G investments transition to 5G, panelists speaking at the ConnecTechAsia 2019 Summit said.

FEATURED RESEARCH

Broadcast Investor: Broadcast deal market May — TV, radio both register big deals: TV deals in the second quarter have not reached the volume of the first quarter's transactions, but May still delivered the fifth- and sixth-largest TV deals of the year.

RECENT EARNINGS

Adobe fiscal Q2 revenue jumps 25% YOY, beats estimates: Core EPS for the quarter came to $1.83, exceeding the S&P Global Market Intelligence consensus normalized EPS estimate of $1.78.

Anne Freier, Sylvia Edwards Davis, Charlotte van Hek and Esben Svendsen contributed to this report.
